subject: Re: [junit] Don't show exception messages to users (was assertTrue(true))

messageBody:
Elliotte Harold wrote:
> Kevin Lawrence wrote:
>
>
>>Are you arguing that exception messages can be poorly written because
>>they shouldn't be shown to users, or that exception messages shouldn't
>>be shown to users because they are poorly written ?
>
>
> For instance, if an editor
> such as OpenOffice or Adobe Illustrator reads an XML document and
> discovers it to be malformed, it should not simply tell the user that an
> attribute value is missing a quote on line 232. Again, that's not
> something that makes sense to an end user. However the developer of the
> software would likely understand such a message and find it useful.
> Programmers and end users do not need the same information about problems.
>

So, I am not advocating allowing any low-level exception to bubble up to
a user and I agree that programmers and users need different information.


It's not hard to craft exception messages that make sense to the user. I
am trying to counter the idea that exception messages are always useless
therefore it is OK to write crappy exception messages.


How about this for a simple example ?

if(! ssn.matches(SOCIAL_SECURITY_MASK) ){
throw new InvalidDataException(Messages.format(MESSAGE, ssn));
}

The exception type communicates to the programmer. Any caller can handle
the exception if it makes sense to do so.


If the exception makes it out to the user they see a message like :

"Social security number should match the pattern 999-99-9999. AB-1234-XY
is not a valid social security number."

Kevin
